questions.question: What phenomenon is observed in coordination polymers (CPs) due to martensitic phase transition during both heating and cooling cycles?
What is the key facet for observable TS phenomenon as well as the shape memory effect in some crystals?
What triggers the fast mechanical response in single crystals compared to polymers and liquid crystals?
questions.answer: Dense and long-range ordered packing in single crystals

questions.question: What is the role of anisotropic thermal expansion in the observed thermosalience effect?
questions.answer: Anisotropic thermal expansion precedes the TS effect by showing high expansion coefficients

questions.question: How does the synthesis condition of [PbI2(4F-spy)2], 1, influence its thermosalience effect?
questions.answer: The synthesis by evaporating a DMF solution containing PbI2 and 4F-spy ligand at a 1:2 ratio leads to the formation of crystals that exhibit reversible thermosalience due to martensitic phase transition

questions.question: Is the thermosalience effect in CPs commonly reversible?
questions.answer: False, the reversibility of thermosalience in CPs is rare

questions.question: Does the thermosalience effect in [PbI2(4F-spy)2] occur due to nonmolecular crystal movements?
questions.answer: True, the thermosalience effect is due to the martensitic phase transition causing nonmolecular crystal movements

questions.question: Can the thermosalience effect in [PbI2(4F-spy)2] be repeated for multiple heating-cooling cycles without loss of functionality?
questions.answer: True, the reversible actuation of the CP could be repeated for 20 heating-cooling cycles, suggesting its potential as a multicyclic actuator

questions.question: What experimental technique was used to directly visualize the thermal responsiveness and confirmation of the TS effect?
How does the crystal structure transformation from phase I to phase II at 408 K affect the thermosalience effect?
questions.answer: The transformation from triclinic space group P1Ì… in phase I to monoclinic space group C2/m in phase II is unusual and contributes to the thermosalience effect by redefining crystallographic axes and causing contraction and expansion along the longest crystal dimension
